CatDescriptText: B. Boggs, salesman, Uptown and James Otterson, life insurance salesman, Bellevue, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, November 12, 1960, pg. A1 with question: "If you were President of the United States, would you appoint a Negro to the cabinet?  Do you think there is a Negro or Negroes qualified for a cabinet post?"  Mr. Boggs' answer reads: "Yes, if the Negro happens to be a good man.  But the selection should be made on the basis of qualification and not because of religion or creed...I feel certain that there are some Negroes who have the qualifications to be a cabinet member."  Mr. Otterson's answer reads: "In a democracy if the people are not represented, because they are of a certain group, we don't have a democracy..."
TitMainTitle: Two Frames: Portrait of B. Boggs wearing fedora, eyeglasses, and herringbone jacket, standing on sidewalk on Smithfield Street, Downtown; Portrait of James Otterson wearing fedora and diagonally striped necktie, standing in front of Western Union, Smithfield Street, Downtown
